title: Apple's iPhone addiction: How the tech giant's products keep us hooked
summary: The iPhone is the backbone of Appleâ€™s services business. It generates massive amounts of revenue for the company and is an essential part of its services business. The amount of money Apple makes from iPhone sales every year is so great that it actually outstrips the company's other major revenue stream. If the iPhone turns out to be a dud, Apple may have a serious problem on its hands. The company's executives have been talking up their flagship product so much that it almost seems like an unhealthy obsession.

content.compiledSource:
var d=Object.defineProperty,u=Object.defineProperties;var c=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptors;var a=Object.getOwnPropertySymbols;var i=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty,h=Object.prototype.propertyIsEnumerable;var r=(e,t,s)=>t in e?d(e,t,{enumerable:!0,configurable:!0,writable:!0,value:s}):e[t]=s,n=(e,t)=>{for(var s in t||(t={}))i.call(t,s)&&r(e,s,t[s]);if(a)for(var s of a(t))h.call(t,s)&&r(e,s,t[s]);return e},p=(e,t)=>u(e,c(t));var l=(e,t)=>{var s={};for(var o in e)i.call(e,o)&&t.indexOf(o)<0&&(s[o]=e[o]);if(e!=null&&a)for(var o of a(e))t.indexOf(o)<0&&h.call(e,o)&&(s[o]=e[o]);return s};const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent(s){var o=s,{components:e}=o,t=l(o,["components"]);return mdx(MDXLayout,p(n(n({},layoutProps),t),{components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"}),mdx("h2",null,"iPhone: A brief history"),mdx("p",null,`The iPhone debuted in 2007 as a smartphone that would bridge the gap between computers and telephones. It launched with one of the first app stores to allow easy app discovery on a smartphone. It was a quantum leap in terms of the user experience of mobile phones.
The iPhone\u2019s introduction to the world was, in many ways, a reaction to the growing popularity of feature phones. While smartphone sales were initially muted due to their high cost, feature phone sales were booming.
That all changed in 2007, with the launch of the iPhone. Between 2007 and 2010, smartphone sales exploded from 9% of the market to more than 50%. Apple\u2019s iPhone was a large part of that explosion.`),mdx("h2",null,"iPhone addiction isn\u2019t new"),mdx("p",null,`Even though smartphone usage was exploding, it was all too easy to dismiss addiction to the device itself as a fad. After all, it was a device that many people had just recently acquired access to, and it took some time for the average user to fully explore the capabilities of a smartphone.
That said, there were some early signs of addiction to mobile devices, especially smartphones. For example, in a study published in 2010, 15% of respondents reported feeling \u201Caddicted\u201D to their mobile phones. That may not seem like a lot, but when you consider that respondents were all people who had had mobile phones for at least two years, it paints an interesting picture.`),mdx("h2",null,"iPhone makes up nearly all of Apple\u2019s profit"),mdx("p",null,`In the tech world, there are few things more closely associated with Apple than the iPhone. After all, it\u2019s been the mainstay of the company\u2019s revenue stream for years.
Indeed, Apple\u2019s dependence on iPhone revenue is so great that, according to one recent report, the company\u2019s services revenue is actually lower than the profit generated by the iPhone.
That\u2019s right: The amount of money Apple makes from iPhone sales every year is so great that it actually outstrips the company\u2019s other major revenue stream.
This is a clear indication that the iPhone is far more than just a device: It\u2019s a key part of Apple\u2019s business model.`),mdx("h2",null,"The iPhone is the backbone of Apple\u2019s services business"),mdx("p",null,`Apple\u2019s services segment is a huge part of the company\u2019s overall business. It\u2019s the place where Apple earns money from customers who buy Apple devices but don\u2019t buy things like iPhones.
And it\u2019s an increasingly important part of Apple\u2019s business: Services were the only part of the company\u2019s business that grew during the recent quarter.
Indeed, services are so important to Apple\u2019s future that, according to the company\u2019s executives, they\u2019re heavily dependent on the iPhone.`),mdx("h2",null,"Conclusion"),mdx("p",null,`You don\u2019t have to be a business analyst to see the signs of iPhone addiction at Apple. The company\u2019s executives have been talking up their flagship product so much that it almost seems like an unhealthy obsession. That said, it\u2019s understandable that Apple\u2019s top brass are so obsessed with the iPhone: It generates massive amounts of revenue for the company, and it\u2019s an essential part of the company\u2019s services business. And when you look at the sheer volume of products that Apple has launched, it\u2019s easy to see why they\u2019re so obsessed with iPhone.
Indeed, it\u2019s almost as if Apple has staked its future on the iPhone. If the iPhone turns out to be a dud, Apple may have a serious problem on its hands.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

The Macbook Pro is a computer that has been iterated on for many years now. It is also a computer that has gained popularity for being the go-to laptop for video editors and other professionals who rely on the performance of their computer when it comes to editing video or images, like photographers. This article will go into detail about some of the most common mistakes Macbook Pro owners make with their machine and how you can avoid making these same mistakes yourself if you own one.
With so many different versions of the Macbook Pro available on the market right now, it\u2019s easy to get confused about which features you need as an owner of this device and which ones you don\u2019t. Here are some tips and tricks to keep in mind if you own a Macbook Pro:`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

The digital age has made it possible for people to work from virtually anywhere at any time. As a result, more people are leaving the office behind and working remotely or taking up independent contracting gigs, which is why we\u2019re seeing so many young professionals ditch cubicles for coffee shops and other remote-friendly offices.
Working from home, going independent, or collaborating with coworkers online means millennials have given rise to what some have called \u201Cthe gig economy.\u201D It\u2019s also prompted a shift in the types of companies people choose to work for and what skills they need to get hired in those roles \u2014 regardless of where they do that work. If you\u2019re looking to join this world of work in 2020, here\u2019s everything you need to know:`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

Every operation we do in our daily lives involves some kind of technology. This can range from how we get to work, to the way we buy and sell goods and services, the sources we use for information and the way we stay in touch with friends and family. Everything has been made easier thanks to technology. Artificial intelligence is a branch of computer science that enables devices or algorithms to act in a human-like manner as observed in humans and animals.
AI has many practical applications, such as automatically tagging images on social media sites, detecting spam email filters, or self-driving cars. In this blog post, you will learn more about artificial intelligence, its implications on society and potential future implications of AI on jobs and everyday life.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

The world is on the cusp of an exciting new era in wireless technology, as the rollout of fifth generation (5G) cellular networks begins across the globe.
Even though 4G LTE coverage is widespread and newer 5G networks aren\u2019t quite ready for large-scale implementation just yet, carriers around the world are already testing out pre-Release 15 5G network services. Several national operators have already begun deploying their 5G network infrastructure, while others are set to follow suit in the coming months. The race is on to lead the way in this cutting-edge technology and reap the benefits that come with it. This is particularly true of the company\u2019s laptop offerings, like the MacBook Pro. These computers are sleek, powerful, and packed with features that make them stand out from their Windows-based competitors. But as great as these features may be on paper, not all Macbook Pros are created equal. Even if you get a high-end model with all of the bells and whisters that you want and need, it won\u2019t last forever. Even the sturdiest of laptops will break down eventually. What\u2019s important is how well equipped you are to handle these breakdowns when they happen. If your computer starts acting weird or giving you red flags about its performance, it\u2019s probably time to take action sooner rather than later. Here are 3 reasons why your Macbook Pro may be lying to you:"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
